question.title: Is it necessary to rename Java packages when transferring an application to a client with a different domain?
question.body:
I'm developing a Java application where the package names follow the reversed domain name convention (e.g., com.myname.project). I plan to host the app on my own domain for demonstration purposes.

If the application is later adopted by a client or company with their own domain, and they want the code to reflect their domain (e.g., changing com.myname to com.clientname), is it necessary or recommended to rename the packages?

Is this a common practice in real-world projects?

How difficult or routine is it to refactor all package names in a mature Java project?

Are there best practices or tools (e.g., in IntelliJ IDEA) to make this process easier? (refactoring of code)

question_comments.body: Iâ€™m voting to re-open this Question. Much improved after extensive rewriting.
@BasilBourque It's common practice to let package names start with the reverse domain name of the "owner".

IF "they want the code to reflect their domain" then it is necessary, but only because they want it and if you want to do what they want (recommended? well, depends on relation to client) It sure is not necessary, nor recommended from the code or developer view. The (only) reason for using the domain names is to avoid naming conflicts with code from other companies (can be a problem if all code suppliers of that client use the same package name, as example)

Where/how is your app runs has nothing to do with the Domain where your app is available. Think of it like two cog gears. Your domain is one cog and your app is a different cog, at some point you connect then together. The only exception to that is if you app has hard coded references to the cog you connected it to :) As for the package name it can really be anything, though your company might have strict rules on naming, as in it needs to be specific to the company so you would eventually need to refactor the packages.

There is no structural element called "domain" in a Java app. Java organizes code by package and optionally by module. You need to rewrite your Question to clarify what you really mean. And delete most of your prose about your company etc.; it is just a distraction. Focus like a laser beam on your technical issue. And rewrite your title to summarize that specific technical issue.
